sen.j: 築地塀（ついじべい）とは泥土をつき固めて作った塀。
sen.e: A 'tsuijibei' or roofed mud wall is a wall made of rammed earth.

sen.j: 単に「築地」（ついじ）ともいう。
sen.e: It is also simply called tsuiji.

sen.j: 石垣の基礎に柱を立てて貫 (建築)を通した骨組みを木枠で挟み、そこに練り土を入れて棒でつき固める「版築」という方法で作られる物が多い。
sen.e: Most mud walls are made by a method called 'hanchiku' in which columns are built on a stone wall foundation and a frame made with horizontal planks is built and then encased in a wooden frame and mud is poured in and rammed with a stick.

sen.j: 塀の上には簡便な小屋組を設け、瓦や板などで葺いたものが多く見られる。
sen.e: A simple roof truss is built on top of the wall and this is usually covered with tiles or planks.

sen.e: Many such mud walls were built around aristocratic residences, temples or government quarters from olden days and even now they can be seen around the Imperial Palace and temples.
